member.name: M:Catkeys.Process_.GetProcessName(System.Int32,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gets process executable file name without ".exe", or full path. Returns null if fails.
member.param: Process id. If you have a window, use its ProcessId property.
Get full path. Note: Fails to get full path if the process belongs to another user session, unless current process is admin; also fails to get full path of some system processes.
When the fast API QueryFullProcessImageName fails, don't try to use another much slower API WTSEnumerateProcesses. Not used if fullPath is true.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Process_.GetProcessesByName(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Returns list of process id of all processes whose names match processName. Returns empty list if there are no matching processes.
member.param: Process name. String format: wildcard expression.

If false, processName is filename without ".exe". If true, processName is full path. Note: Fails to get full path if the process belongs to another user session, unless current process is admin; also fails to get full path of some system processes.
member.exception: processName is "" or null. Invalid wildcard expression ("**options|" or regular expression).

member.name: M:Catkeys.Process_.GetFileNameWithoutExe(System.String)
member.summary: Removes path and ".exe" extension from file name. Does not remove other extensions.
member.param: A file name or full path. Can be null.

member.name: T:Catkeys.Process_.LibProcessHandle
member.summary: Opens and manages a process handle. Calls API CloseHandle in Dispose (which normally is implicitly called at the end of using(...){...}) or in finalizer (which is called later by the GC).

member.name: M:Catkeys.Process_.LibProcessHandle.#ctor(System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Attaches a kernel handle to this new object. No exception when handle is invalid.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Process_.LibProcessHandle.#ctor(System.Int32,System.UInt32)
member.summary: Opens a process handle. Calls API OpenProcess. No exception when fails; use Is0. Supports Native.GetError().
member.param: Process id.
Desired access, as documented in MSDN -> OpenProcess.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Process_.LibProcessHandle.#ctor(Catkeys.Wnd,System.UInt32)
member.summary: Opens window's process handle. This overload is more powerful: if API OpenProcess fails, it tries GetProcessHandleFromHwnd, which can open higher integrity level processes, but only if current process is uiAccess and desiredAccess includes only PROCESS_DUP_HANDLE, PROCESS_VM_OPERATION, PROCESS_VM_READ, PROCESS_VM_WRITE, SYNCHRONIZE. No exception when fails; use Is0. Supports Native.GetError().
member.param: Window.
Api.PROCESS_

member.name: T:Catkeys.Process_.LibProcessWaitHandle
member.summary: Process handle that is inherited from WaitHandle. When don't need to wait, use LibProcessHandle, it's more lightweight and has more creation methods. Or use .NET Process class.

member.summary: Allocates, writes and reads memory in other process.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Process_.Memory.ProcessHandle
member.summary: Process handle. Opened with access PROCESS_VM_OPERATION | PROCESS_VM_READ | PROCESS_VM_WRITE.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Process_.Memory.Mem
member.summary: Address of memory allocated in that process. Invalid in this process.

member.summary: Opens window's process handle and optionally allocates memory in that process.
member.param: A window in that process.
If not 0, allocates this number of bytes of memory in that process.
member.remarks: This is the preferred constructor when the process has windows. It works with windows of UAC High integrity level when this process is Medium+uiAccess.
member.exception: w invalid.
Failed to open process handle (usually because of UAC) or allocate memory.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Process_.Memory.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Opens window's process handle and optionally allocates memory in that process.
member.param: Process id.
If not 0, allocates this number of bytes of memory in that process.
member.exception: Failed to open process handle (usually because of UAC) or allocate memory.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Process_.Memory.WriteUnicodeString(System.String,System.Int32)
member.summary: Copies a string from this process to the memory allocated in that process by the constructor. In that process the string is written as '\0'-terminated UTF-16 string. For it is used (s.Length+1)*2 bytes of memory in that process (+1 for the '\0', *2 because UTF-16 character size is 2 bytes). Returns false if fails.
member.param: A string in this process.
Offset in the memory allocated by the constructor.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Process_.Memory.WriteAnsiString(System.String,System.Int32,System.Text.Encoding)
member.summary: Copies a string from this process to the memory allocated in that process by the constructor. In that process the string is written as '\0'-terminated ANSI string, in default or specified encoding. Returns false if fails.
member.param: A string in this process. Normal C# string (UTF-16), not ANSI.
Offset in the memory allocated by the constructor.
If null, uses system's default ANSI encoding.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Process_.Memory.ReadUnicodeString(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Copies a string from the memory in that process allocated by the constructor to this process. Returns the copies string, or null if fails. In that process the string must be in Unicode UTF-16 format (ie not ANSI).
member.param: Number of characters to copy. In both processes a character is 2 bytes.
Offset in the memory allocated by the constructor.

member.name: T:Catkeys.Process_.UacInfo
member.summary: Holds access token (security info) of a process and provides various security info, eg UAC integrity level.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Process_.UacInfo.TokenHandle
member.summary: Access token handle.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Process_.UacInfo.Failed
member.summary: Gets true if the last called property function failed. Normally getting properties should never fail. Only the GetOfProcess method can fail, then it returns null.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Process_.UacInfo.Elevation
member.summary: Gets process UAC elevation type. Elevation types: Full - runs as administrator (High or System integrity level). Limited - runs as standard user (Medium, Medium+UIAccess or Low integrity level) on administrator user session. Default - all processes in this user session run as admin, or all as standard user. Can be: non-administrator user session; service session; UAC is turned off. Unknown - failed to get. Normally it never happens; only GetOfProcess can fail, then it returns null. This property is rarely useful. Instead use other properties of this class.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Process_.UacInfo.IsUIAccess
member.summary: Returns true if the process has uiAccess property. A uiAccess process can access/automate all windows of processes running in the same user session. Most processes don't have this property and cannot access/automate windows of higher integrity level (High, System, Middle+uiAccess) processes and Windows 8 store apps. For example, cannot send keys and Windows messages. Note: High IL (admin) processes also can have this property, therefore IsUIAccess is not the same as IntegrityLevelAndUIAccess==IL.UIAccess (IntegrityLevelAndUIAccess returns IL.UIAccess only for Medium+uiAccess processes; for High+uiAccess processes it returns IL.High). Some Windows API work slightly differently with uiAccess and non-uiAccess admin processes. This property is rarely useful. Instead use other properties of this class.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Process_.UacInfo.IsAppContainer
member.summary: Returns true if the process is a Windows Store app.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Process_.UacInfo.IntegrityLevel
member.summary: Gets process UAC integrity level (IL). IL from lowest to highest value: Untrusted - the most limited rights. Very rare. Low - very limited rights. Used by Internet Explorer tab processes, Windows Store apps. Medium - limited rights. Most processes (unless UAC turned off). UIAccess - Medium IL + can access/automate High IL windows (user interface). Note: Only the property can return UIAccess. This property returns High instead (the same as in Process Explorer). High - most rights. Processes that run as administrator. System - almost all rights. Services, some system processes. Protected - undocumented. Never seen. Unknown - failed to get IL. Never seen. The IL enum member values can be used like if(x.IntegrityLevel > IL.Medium) ... . If UAC is turned off, most non-service processes on administrator account have High IL; on non-administrator - Medium.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Process_.UacInfo.IntegrityLevelAndUIAccess
member.summary: The same as IntegrityLevel, but can return UIAccess.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Process_.UacInfo.GetOfProcess(System.Int32)
member.summary: Opens process access token and creates UacInfo object that holds it. Returns UacInfo object. Then you can use its properties. Returns null if failed. For example fails for services and some other processes if current process is not administrator. To get UacInfo of this process, instead use UacInfo.ThisProcess.
member.param: Process id. If you have a window, use its ProcessId property.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Process_.UacInfo.ThisProcess
member.summary: Gets UacInfo object of current process.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Process_.UacInfo.IsAdmin
member.summary: Returns true if current process is running as administrator, ie if the user belongs to the local Administrators group and the process is not limited by UAC. This function for example can be used to check whether you can write to protected locations in the file system and registry.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Process_.UacInfo.IsUacDisabled
member.summary: Returns true if UAC is disabled (turned off) on this Windows 7 computer. On Windows 8 and 10 UAC cannot be disabled, although you can disable UAC elevation consent dialogs.

member.name: T:Catkeys.String_
member.summary: Adds extension methods to System.String. Also adds StringComparison.Ordinal[IgnoreCase] versions of .NET String methods that use StringComparison.CurrentCulture by default. See https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms973919.aspx Extension method names have suffix _. Most of these extension methods throw NullReferenceException if called for a string variable that is null.

member.name: M:Catkeys.String_.Like_(System.String,System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary:
Compares this string with a string that possibly contains wildcard characters. Returns true if the strings match.
Wildcard characters: * - zero or more of any characters. ? - any character.
member.param: This string. If null, returns true if pattern is null. If "", returns true if pattern is "" or "*".
String that possibly contains wildcard characters. If null, returns true if this string is null. If "", returns true if this string is "". If "*", always returns true except when this string is null.
Case-insensitive.
member.remarks: Like all String_ functions, performs ordinal comparison, ie does not depend on current culture. Much faster than Regex.IsMatch and not much slower than Equals_, EndsWith_, IndexOf_ etc.

member.name: M:Catkeys.String_.Like_(System.String,System.Boolean,System.String[])
member.summary: Calls Like_(patterns[i], ignoreCase) for each wildcard pattern specified in the argument list until it returns true. Returns 1-based index of matching pattern, or 0 if none.

member.name: M:Catkeys.String_.ToInt32_(System.String,System.Int32,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Converts part of string to int. Returns the int value, or 0 if fails to convert. Fails to convert when string is null, "", does not begin with a number or the number is too big. Unlike int.Parse and Convert.ToInt32: The number in string can be followed by more text, like "123text". Has startIndex parameter that allows to get number from middle, like "text123text". Gets the end of the number part. No exception when cannot convert. Supports hexadecimal format, like "0x1E" or "0x1e". Much faster.
member.param: Offset in string where to start parsing.
Receives offset in string where the number part ends. If fails to convert, receives 0.
member.remarks: The number can begin with ASCII spaces, tabs or newlines, like " 5". The number can be with "-" or "+", like "-5", but not like "- 5". Fails if the number is greater than +- uint.MaxValue (0xffffffff). The return value becomes negative if the number is greater than int.MaxValue, for example "0xffffffff" is -1, but it becomes correct if assigned to uint (need cast). Does not support non-integer numbers; for example, for "3.5E4" returns 3 and sets numberEndIndex=1.
member.exception: startIndex is less than 0 or greater than string length.

member.name: M:Catkeys.String_.ToInt32_(System.String,System.Int32)
member.summary: This overload does not have parameter numberEndIndex.

member.name: M:Catkeys.String_.ToInt32_(System.String)
member.summary: This overload does not have parameters.

member.name: M:Catkeys.String_.ToInt64_(System.String,System.Int32,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Converts part of string to long. Returns the long value, or 0 if fails to convert. Fails to convert when string is null, "", does not begin with a number or the number is too big. Unlike long.Parse and Convert.ToInt64: The number in string can be followed by more text, like "123text". Has startIndex parameter that allows to get number from middle, like "text123text". Gets the end of the number part. No exception when cannot convert. Supports hexadecimal format, like "0x1E" or "0x1e". Much faster.
member.param: Offset in string where to start parsing.
Receives offset in string where the number part ends. If fails to convert, receives 0.
member.remarks: The number can begin with ASCII spaces, tabs or newlines, like " 5". The number can be with "-" or "+", like "-5", but not like "- 5". Fails if the number is greater than +- ulong.MaxValue (0xffffffffffffffff). The return value becomes negative if the number is greater than long.MaxValue, for example "0xffffffffffffffff" is -1, but it becomes correct if assigned to ulong (need cast). Does not support non-integer numbers; for example, for "3.5E4" returns 3 and sets numberEndIndex=1.
member.exception: startIndex is less than 0 or greater than string length.

member.name: M:Catkeys.String_.ToInt64_(System.String,System.Int32)
member.summary: This overload does not have parameter numberEndIndex.

member.name: M:Catkeys.String_.ToInt64_(System.String)
member.summary: This overload does not have parameters.

member.name: M:Catkeys.String_.ToIntAndString_(System.String,System.String@)
member.summary: Converts string to int (calls ) and gets string part that follows the number. For example, for string "123text" sets the tail variable = "text" and returns 123. For string like "123" sets tail = "". If fails to convert, sets tail = null. Skips 1 ASCII space or tab character after the number part. For example, for string "123 text" sets tail = "text", not " text". Everything else is the same as with ToInt32_.
member.param: A string variable. Can be this variable.

member.name: T:Catkeys.Wildex
member.summary: This class implements wildcard expression parsing and matching (comparing). Typically used in 'find' functions. For example, Wnd.Find uses it to compare window name, class name and program. The 'find' function creates a Wildex instance (which parses the wildcard expression), then calls for each item (eg window) to compare some its property text.
member.exception: Invalid **options| or regular expression.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wildex.#ctor(System.String)
member.param: Wildcard expression. null will match null. "" will match "".
member.exception: Invalid **options| or regular expression.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wildex.op_Implicit(System.String)~Catkeys.Wildex
member.summary: Creates new Wildex from wildcard expression string. If the string is null, returns null, else creates and returns new Wildex.
member.param: Wildcard expression.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wildex.Match(System.String)
member.summary: Compares a string with the wildcard expression used to create this . Returns true if they match.
member.param: String. If null, returns true if wildcardExpression was null. If "", returns true if it was "" or "*" or a regular expression that matches "".

member.summary: Simple text (option t, or no *? characters and no t r options). Match() calls .

member.summary: Wildcard (has *? characters and no t r options). Match() calls .

member.summary: Regular expression (option r). Match() calls .

member.name: F:Catkeys.Wildex.WildType.Multi
member.summary: Multiple parts (option m). Match() calls Match() for each part (see ) and returns true if all negative (option n) parts return true (or there are no such parts) and some positive (no option n) part returns true (or there are no such parts). If you want to implement a different logic, call Match() for each element (instead of calling Match() for this variable).

Custom buttons style. If false - row of classic buttons. If true - column of command-link buttons that can have multiline text.

Additional custom buttons. All will be custom, even if named "OK" etc. List of labels without ids. Can be string like "One|Two|..." or IEnumerable<string>. Button ids will be 1, 2, ... . DefaultButton will be 1 (you can change it later).

member.name: P:Catkeys.TaskDialog.Width
member.summary: Sets the width of the dialog's client area. The actual width will depend on DPI (the Windows "text size" setting). If less than default width, will be used default width.

member.summary: Sets owner window. The owner window will be disabled, and this dialog will be on top of it. This window will be in owner's screen, if screen was not explicitly specified with the property. is ignored.
member.param: Owner window, or one of its child/descendant controls. Can be Control (eg Form) or Wnd (window handle). Can be null.
Show the dialog in the center of the owner window. SetXY and Screen are ignored.
Don't disable the owner window. If false, disables if it belongs to this thread.

member.name: P:Catkeys.TaskDialog.Result
member.summary: Gets selected button id and other results packed in a TDResult variable. It is the same variable as the ShowDialog return value. If the result is still unavailable (eg the dialog still not closed): If called from the same thread that called ShowDialog, returns null. If called from another thread, waits until the dialog is closed and the return value is available. Note that ShowDialogNoWait calls ShowDialog in another thread.

member.name: M:Catkeys.TaskDialog.ThreadWaitOpen
member.summary: Can be used by other threads to wait until the dialog is open. If returns true, the dialog is open and you can send messages to it. If returns false, the dialog is already closed or failed to show.

member.name: M:Catkeys.TaskDialog.ThreadWaitClosed
member.summary: Can be used by other threads to wait until the dialog is closed.

member.name: P:Catkeys.TaskDialog.IsOpen
member.summary: Returns true if the dialog is open and your code can send messages to it.

member.name: P:Catkeys.TaskDialog.DialogWindow
member.summary: Gets dialog window handle as Wnd. Returns Wnd0 if the dialog is not open.

member.name: P:Catkeys.TaskDialog.Send
member.summary: Allows to modify dialog controls while it is open, and close the dialog. Example: td.Send.Close(); . Example: td.Send.ChangeText2("new text", false); . Example: td.Send.Message(TaskDialog.TDApi.TDM.CLICK_VERIFICATION, 1); .
member.remarks: Can be used only while the dialog is open. Before showing the dialog returns null. After closing the dialog the returned variable is deactivated; its method calls are ignored. Can be used in dialog event handlers. Also can be used in another thread, for example with ShowNoWaitEx and ShowProgressEx.

member.name: T:Catkeys.TaskDialog.TDMessageSender
member.summary: Used to send task dialog API messages, like td.Send.Message(TaskDialog.TDApi.TDM.CLICK_VERIFICATION, 1); .

member.name: M:Catkeys.TaskDialog.TDMessageSender.Message(Catkeys.TaskDialog.TDApi.TDM,Catkeys.LPARAM,Catkeys.LPARAM)
member.summary: Sends a message to the dialog. Call this method while the dialog is open, eg in an event handler. Example (in an event handler): e.dialog.Send.Message(TaskDialog.TDApi.TDM.CLICK_VERIFICATION, 1); Also there are several other functions to send some messages: change text, close dialog, enable/disable buttons, set progress. Reference: task dialog messages. NAVIGATE_PAGE currently not supported.

member.param: A button id or some other number that will be returned by ShowDialog.

member.summary: Enables or disables a button. Call this method while the dialog is open, eg in an event handler. Example: d.Created += e => { e.dialog.Send.EnableButton(4, false); }; Sends message TaskDialog.TDApi.TDM.ENABLE_BUTTON.

member.summary: Shows task dialog. Returns selected button id and other results packed in a TDResult variable (more info in Remarks).
member.param: Main instruction. Bigger font.
Text below main instruction.
See .
Owner window or null. See .
Text that the user can show and hide.
Text at the bottom of the dialog. Icon can be specified like "i|Text", where i is: x error, ! warning, i info, v shield, a app.
Title bar text. If omitted, null or "", uses .
Adds radio buttons. A list of strings "id text" separated by |, like "1 One|2 Two|3 Three".
If not null/"", shows a check box with this text. To make it checked, append "|true", "|check" or "|checked".

If not 0, auto-close the dialog after this time (seconds) and set result's Button property = .
member.remarks: The returned TDResult variable has these properties: selected button id, selected radio button id, check box state. Tip: TDResult supports implicit cast to int. You can use code switch(TaskDialog.ShowEx(...)) instead of switch(TaskDialog.ShowEx(...).Button) . Tip: For optional parameters use named arguments. Example: TaskDialog.ShowEx("Text.", icon: TDIcon.Info, title: "Title") . This function allows you to use most of the task dialog features, but not all. Alternatively you can create a TaskDialog class instance, set properties and call ShowDialog.
member.exception: Failed to show dialog.

member.name: M:Catkeys.TaskDialog.Show(System.String,System.String,System.String,Catkeys.TDIcon,Catkeys.TDFlags,Catkeys.WndOrControl)
member.summary: Shows task dialog. Returns selected button id.
member.param: Main instruction. Bigger font.
Text below main instruction.

A list of button ids and labels in this format: "id label|id label|...". Example: "1 OK|2 Cancel|5 Save|4 Don't Save". Missing ids are auto-generated, for example "OK|Cancel|100 Custom1|Custom2" is the same as "1 OK|2 Cancel|100 Custom1|101 Custom2". The first in the list button is default, ie responds to the Enter key. For example, "2 No|1 Yes" adds Yes and No buttons and makes No default. Trims newlines around ids and labels. For example, "
1 One
|
2
Two

" is the same as "1 One|2 Two".
To create keyboard shortcuts, use & character in custom button labels. Use && for literal &. Example: "1 &Tuesday[]2 T&hursday[]3 Saturday && Sunday".
There are 6 common buttons: OK, Yes, No, Retry, Cancel, Close. Buttons that have other labels are custom buttons. How common buttons are different: 1. TDFlags.CommandLinks does not change their style. 2. They have keyboard shortcuts that cannot be changed. Inserting & in a label makes it a custom button. 3. Button Cancel can be selected with the Esc key. It also adds X (Close) button in title bar, which selects Cancel. 4. Always displayed in standard order (eg Yes No, never No Yes). But you can for example use "2 No|1 Yes" to set default button = No. 5. The displayed button label is localized, ie different when the Windows UI language is not English.
If omitted, null or "", the dialog will have OK button, id 1. You can use in flags to change the style of custom buttons. See also: .
Owner window or null. See .
member.remarks: Calls . Tip: For optional parameters use named arguments. Example: TaskDialog.Show("Text.", icon: TDIcon.Info) .
member.exception: Failed to show dialog.

member.name: T:Catkeys.CsvTable
member.summary: Parses and composes CSV text. Stores CSV table data in memory as a List of string arrays. CSV is a text format used to store a single table of data in human-readable/editable way. It is a list of lines (called rows or records) containing one or more values (called fields or cells) separated by a separator character. There is no strictly defined CSV standard. CsvTable uses these rules: Fields containg characters (default ','), characters (default '"') and multiple lines must be enclosed in characters. Example: "ab, cd". Each Quote character in such fields must be escaped (replaced) with two characters. Example: "ab ""cd"" ef". Fields that start or end with ASCII space or tab characters must be enclosed in characters, unless is false. Example: " ab ". Rows in CSV text can have different field count.

member.name: M:Catkeys.CsvTable.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance and parses CSV text, the same as . Uses default , and values (',', '"', true).
member.param: CSV text.
member.exception: Invalid CSV, eg contains incorrectly enclosed fields.

member.name: P:Catkeys.CsvTable.Data
member.summary: Gets the internal List containing rows as string arrays. It's not a copy; changing it will change the data of this CsvTable variable. You can do anything with the List. For example, sort it, find rows containing certain field values, get/set field values directly, add/remove rows directly. All row arrays have Length equal to , and it must remain so; you can change Length, but then need to call ColumnCount=newLength.

example.code: x.Data.Sort((a,b) => string.CompareOrdinal(a[0], b[0]));

member.name: P:Catkeys.CsvTable.Separator
member.summary: Sets or gets the field separator character used when parsing and composing CSV text. Initially it is ','.

member.name: P:Catkeys.CsvTable.Quote
member.summary: Sets or gets the quote character used when parsing and composing CSV text. Initially it is '"'.

member.name: P:Catkeys.CsvTable.TrimSpaces
member.summary: Whether to ignore ASCII space and tab characters at the beginning and end of fields when parsing CSV. Initially true.

member.name: M:Catkeys.CsvTable.FromString(System.String)
member.summary: Parses CSV text and stores all data in internal List of string arrays. Depends on these properties: (initially ','), (initially '"'), (initially true).
member.param: CSV text. If rows in CSV text have different field count, the longest row sets the property and all row array lenghts; array elements of missing CSV fields will be null.
member.exception: Invalid CSV, eg contains incorrectly enclosed fields.

member.name: M:Catkeys.CsvTable.ToString
member.summary: Composes CSV text from the internal List of string arrays. Depends on these properties: (initially ','), (initially '"').

member.name: P:Catkeys.CsvTable.RowCount
member.summary: Gets or sets row count. The 'get' function simply returns the Count property of the internal List of string arrays. The 'set' function can add new rows or remove rows at the end.

member.name: P:Catkeys.CsvTable.ColumnCount
member.summary: Gets or sets column count. The 'get' function returns the length of all string arrays in the internal List. The 'set' function can add new columns or remove columns at the right.

member.summary: Gets or sets a field.
member.param: 0-based row index. With the 'set' function it can be negative or equal to ; then adds new row.
0-based column index. With the 'set' function it can be >= and < 1000; then makes ColumnCount = column + 1.

member.param: 0-based row index. With the 'set' function it can be negative or equal to ; then adds new row.

Row fields. Can be a string array or multiple string arguments. Does not copy the array, unless its Length is less than . Adds new columns if array Length (or the number of string arguments) is greater than ColumnCount.

member.name: T:Catkeys.Time
member.summary: Time functions. Get, wait, doevents, timer, precision.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Time.Microseconds
member.summary: Gets the number of microseconds elapsed since Windows startup. The precision is 1 microsecond.
member.remarks: Uses API QueryPerformanceCounter. Includes the computer sleep/hibernate time (see also ). Independent of computer clock time changes. MSDN article: Acquiring high-resolution time stamps.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Time.Milliseconds
member.summary: Gets the number of milliseconds elapsed since Windows startup. The precision is 1 millisecond. See also .
member.remarks: Uses API QueryPerformanceCounter. Includes the computer sleep/hibernate time (see also ). Independent of computer clock time changes. Unlike Environment.TickCount, this function is more precise and returns a 64-bit value that will not roll over in 100 years from the most recent system boot.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Time.MillisecondsWithoutSleepTime
member.summary: Gets the number of milliseconds elapsed since Windows startup, not including time the system spends in sleep or hibernation. The precision is 1-16 milliseconds, depending on the system wait precision (see ).
member.remarks: Uses API QueryUnbiasedInterruptTime. Independent of computer clock time changes. This function can be used to implement a timeout in 'wait for something' functions, when repeatedly checking a condition.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Time.Wait(System.Double)
member.summary: Suspends this thread for the specified amount of time. The same as , but uses seconds, not milliseconds.
member.param: The number of seconds to wait. The smallest value is 0.001 (1 ms).
member.exception: timeS is less than 0 or greater than 2147483 (int.MaxValue/1000, 24.8 days).
member.remarks: Calls . Does not process events and messages, therefore should not be used in threads with windows, timers or COM events. Supports asynchronous procedure calls. Usually waits longer by 1-15 milliseconds, but not shorter. It depends on the system wait precision (see ). If the computer goes to sleep or hibernate during that time, the real time is timeS + the sleep/hibernate time.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Time.Sleep(System.Int32)
member.summary: Suspends this thread for the specified amount of time. The same as , but uses milliseconds, not seconds; and supports Timeout.Infinite.
member.param: The number of milliseconds to wait. The smallest value is 1. Also can be .
member.remarks: Calls . Does not process events and messages, therefore should not be used with big timeMS in threads with windows, timers or COM events. Supports asynchronous procedure calls. Usually waits longer by 1-15 milliseconds, but not shorter. It depends on the system wait precision (see ). If the computer goes to sleep or hibernate during that time, the real time is timeS + the sleep/hibernate time.
member.exception: timeMS is negative and not Timeout.Infinite.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Time.SleepDoEvents(System.Int32)
member.summary: Partially suspends this thread for the specified amount of time, during which processes events and messages.
member.param: The number of milliseconds to wait. The smallest value is 1. Also can be .
member.remarks: Unlike , this function retrieves and dispatches all Windows messages, including posted (key/mouse input, window paint, timer and other). Also calls event handlers, hook procedures, etc. Supports asynchronous procedure calls. This function can be used in threads with windows. However usually there are better ways, for example timer, other thread, async/await/Task. Be careful, this function is as dangerous as . In some places does not work as expected, for example in Form/Control mouse event handlers .NET blocks other mouse events. In threads without windows and timers usually don't need to process posted messages, but in some cases need to process sent messages, some events, hooks etc. Then you can instead use , like Thread.CurrentThread.Join(1000);. Calls API MsgWaitForMultipleObjectsEx and .
member.exception: timeMS is negative and not Timeout.Infinite.
Any exceptions thrown by functions that are executed while waiting (event handlers etc).

member.name: M:Catkeys.Time.DoEvents
member.summary: Retrieves and dispatches messages from the message queue of current thread.
member.remarks: If this thread has a .NET message loop (), calls . Else uses more lightweight API functions PeekMessage, TranslateMessage and DispatchMessage. Be careful, this function is as dangerous as .
member.exception: Any exceptions thrown by functions that are executed while dispatching messages (event handlers etc).

member.name: M:Catkeys.Time.SetTimer(System.Int32,System.Boolean,System.Action{Catkeys.Time.Timer_},System.Object)
member.summary: Sets new timer for this thread. Returns new Timer_ object that can be used to change or stop the timer if you want to do it not in the callback function; usually don't need it.
member.param: Time interval (period) of calling the callback function, milliseconds. Min interval is 10; if this parameter is 0-9, uses 10. Max interval is int.MaxValue.
Call the callback function once, not repeatedly. The timer will be stopped before calling the callback function.
A callback function (delegate), for example lambda.
Something to pass to the callback function as Timer_.Tag.
member.remarks: Uses class Time.Timer_, which calls API SetTimer. Similar to System.Windows.Forms.Timer, but more lightweight, for example does not create a hidden window. The callback function will be called in this thread. This thread must must get/dispatch posted messages, eg call Application.Run() or Form.ShowModal() or TaskDialog.Show(). The callback function is not called while this thread does not do it. The timer interval precision is 15 ms.

member.name: T:Catkeys.Time.Timer_
member.summary: Manages a timer for this thread. Calls API SetTimer and API KillTimer. Similar to System.Windows.Forms.Timer, but more lightweight, for example does not create a hidden window. Used by Time.SetTimer, more info there.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Time.Timer_.Tag
member.summary: Some object or value attached to this Timer_ variable. Can be set with this property or with Time.SetTimer.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Time.Timer_.#ctor(System.Action{Catkeys.Time.Timer_},System.Object)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance. Used by .

member.name: M:Catkeys.Time.Timer_.Start(System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Starts timer. If already started, resets and changes its period.
member.param: Time interval (period) of calling the callback function, milliseconds.
Call the callback function once, not repeatedly. The timer will be stopped before calling the callback function.
member.remarks: If already started, this function must be called in same thread.
member.exception: API SetTimer returned 0. Unlikely.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Time.Timer_.Stop
member.summary: Stops the timer.
member.remarks: Your callback function will never be called after this, even if a timer period is elapsed. Later you can call Start() again. Calling Stop() is optional. Must be called in same thread.

member.name: T:Catkeys.Time.SystemWaitPrecision
member.summary: Changes the precision of wait functions. Calls API timeBeginPeriod, which requests a minimum resolution (period) for various system timers and wait functions. Normal period on Windows 7-10 is 15.625 ms, minimal 1 ms. This class can temporarily make it smaller. It is applied to all threads and processes. The new period is revoked when disposing the variable or when this process ends. See example. Other applications can change it too. For example, Firefox and other web browsers temporarily set period 1 ms when opening a web page. The system uses the smallest period (highest precision) that currently is set by any application. You cannot make it bigger than current value. It is not recommended to keep small period for a long time. It can be bad for power saving. This does not change the minimal period of SetTimer.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Time.SystemWaitPrecision.#ctor(System.Int32)
member.summary: Calls API timeBeginPeriod.
member.param: Period, in milliseconds. Should be 1 - 16.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Time.SystemWaitPrecision.Dispose
member.summary: Calls API timeEndPeriod.

member.name: T:Catkeys.Wnd
member.summary: A variable of Wnd type represents a native window or control. It contains native window handle, also known as HWND. Wnd functions can be used with windows and controls of any process/thread. Wnd functions also can be used with .NET Form and Control instances, like Wnd w=(Wnd)netControl; w.Method(...); or ((Wnd)netControl).Method(...);.
member.remarks:
There are two main types of windows - top-level windows and controls. Controls are child windows of top-level windows.
More functions are in the nested classes - Wnd.Misc, Wnd.Misc.Desktop etc. They are used rarely, mostly in programming, not in automation scripts.
What happens when a Wnd function fails:
Functions that get window properties don't throw exceptions. They return false/0/null/empty. Most of them support , and it is mentioned in function documentation.
Many functions that change window properties throw exception. Exceptions are listed in function documentation. Almost all these functions throw only .
Other functions that change window properties return false. They are more often used in programming than in automation scripts.
When a 'find' function does not find the window or control, it returns Wnd0 (window handle 0). Then will return true.
If a function does not follow these rules, it is mentioned in function documentation.
Many functions fail if the window's process has higher UAC integrity level (aministrator, uiAccess) than this process, unless this process has uiAccess level. Especially the functions that change window properties. Some functions that still work: Activate, ActivateLL, ShowMinimized, ShowNotMinimized, ShowNotMinMax, Close.
The Wnd type can be used with native Windows API functions wihout casting. Use Wnd for the parameter type in the declaration, like [DllImport(...)] static extern bool NativeFunction(Wnd hWnd, ...).
See also: MSDN article Window Features.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.op_Explicit(System.Windows.Forms.Control)~Catkeys.Wnd
member.summary: Gets the window handle as Wnd from a System.Windows.Forms.Control (or Form etc) variable. The same as the extension method Wnd_(). If the handle is still not created, the Control auto-creates it (hidden window).

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.op_Explicit(Catkeys.Wnd)~System.Windows.Forms.Control

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.Misc.WaitForAnActiveWindow
member.summary: Waits while there is no active window. It sometimes happens after closing, minimizing or switching the active window, briefly until another window becomes active. Waits max 500 ms, then returns false if there is no active window. Processes Windows messages that are in the message queue of this thread. Don't need to call this after calling functions of this library.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.Misc.AllowActivate
member.summary: Temporarily enables this process to activate windows with API SetForegroundWindow. Returns false if fails (unlikely). In some cases you may need this function because Windows often disables SetForegroundWindow to not allow applications to activate their windows while the user is working (using keyboard/mouse) with the currently active window. Then SetForegroundWindow just makes the window's taskbar button flash which indicates that the windows wants attention. More info: SetForegroundWindow. Usually you don't call SetForegroundWindow directly. It is called by some other functions, for example Form.Show. Don't need to call this function before calling functions of this library that activate windows.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.Misc.WindowClass.Register(System.String,Catkeys.Native.WNDPROC,System.Int32,System.UInt32,Catkeys.Wnd.Misc.WindowClass.WndClassEx)
member.summary: Registers new window class. Returns new WindowClass variable that holds class atom and other data. Calls API RegisterClassEx.
member.param: Class name.
Window procedure delegate. This variable will keep a reference to it to prevent garbage-collecting.
Size of extra window memory which can be accessed with SetWindowLong/GetWindowLong with >=0 offset. Example: IntPtr.Size.
Class style.
Can be used to specify API WNDCLASSEX fields not specified in parameters. If not used, the function sets: hCursor = arrow; hbrBackground = COLOR_BTNFACE+1; others = 0/null/Zero.
member.exception: Failed, for example if the class already exists.
member.remarks: The actual class name is like "MyClass.2", where "MyClass" is className and "2" is current appdomain id. The property returns it. If style does not have CS_GLOBALCLASS and ex is null or its hInstance field is not set, for hInstance uses exe module handle. Not thread-safe.

member.summary: Registers new window class that extends an existing class. Returns new WindowClass variable that holds class atom and other data. Calls API GetClassInfoEx and API RegisterClassEx.
member.param: Existing class name.
New class name.
Window procedure delegate. This variable will keep a reference to it to prevent garbage-collecting.
Size of extra window memory not including extra memory of base class. Can be accessed with SetMyLong/GetMyLong. Example: IntPtr.Size.
If false, the function removes CS_GLOBALCLASS style.
If the base class is global (CS_GLOBALCLASS style), don't use this parameter, else pass the module handle of the exe or dll that registered the base class.
member.exception: Failed, for example if the class already exists or class baseClassName does not exist.
member.remarks: The actual class name is like "MyClass.2", where "MyClass" is className and "2" is current appdomain identifer. The property returns it. Not thread-safe.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.Misc.WindowClass.InterDomainRegister(System.String,Catkeys.Native.WNDPROC,System.Int32,System.UInt32,Catkeys.Wnd.Misc.WindowClass.WndClassEx)
member.summary: Registers new window class that can be used by all app domains of this process. Returns class atom. Calls API RegisterClassEx.
member.param: Class name.
Window procedure. Can be classic window procedure that calls API DefWindowProc. Don't need to protect it from GC. If null, will use DefWindowProc as window procedure.
Size of extra window memory which can be accessed with SetWindowLong/GetWindowLong with >=0 offset. Example: IntPtr.Size.
Class style. Adds CS_GLOBALCLASS.

Can be used to specify API WNDCLASSEX fields not specified in parameters. If not used, the function sets: hCursor = arrow; hbrBackground = COLOR_BTNFACE+1; others = 0/null/Zero. Always uses hInstance=Zero and adds style CS_GLOBALCLASS.
member.exception: Failed, for example if the class already exists and was registered not with this function.
member.remarks: This function can be called multiple times for the same class, for example called once in each app domain. Next time it just returns class atom. Each app domain that calls this function uses its own instance of window procedure delegate. The window class remains registered until this process ends. Don't need to unregister. Thread-safe.

member.summary: Shows or hides desktop. If there are non-minimized main windows, minimizes them. Else restores windows recently minimized by this function.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.Misc.Desktop.MinimizeWindows
member.summary: Minimizes main windows.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.Misc.Desktop.CascadeWindows
member.summary: Cascades non-minimized main windows.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.Misc.Desktop.TileWindows(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Arranges non-minimized main windows horizontally or vertically.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.Misc.Desktop.UndoMinimizeEtc
member.summary: Restores windows recently minimized, cascaded or tiled with other functions of this class.

member.name: T:Catkeys.Wnd.Misc.WinFormsControlNames
member.summary: Gets programming names of .NET Windows Forms controls. Usually each control has a unique name. It is useful to identify controls without a classic name/text. Control id of these controls is not constant and cannot be used.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.Misc.WinFormsControlNames.#ctor(Catkeys.Wnd)
member.summary: Prepares to get control names.
member.param: Any top-level or child window of that process.
member.exception: w invalid.
Failed to allocate process memory (see ) needed to get control names, usually because of UAC.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.Misc.WinFormsControlNames.GetControlName(Catkeys.Wnd)
member.summary: Gets control name. Returns null if fails or the name is empty.
member.param: The control. Can be a top-level window too. Must be of the same process as the window specified in the constructor.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.Misc.WinFormsControlNames.IsWinFormsControl(Catkeys.Wnd)
member.summary: Returns true if window class name starts with "WindowsForms". Usually it means that we can get Windows Forms control name of w and its child controls.
member.param: The window. Can be top-level or control.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.Misc.WinFormsControlNames.GetSingleControlName(Catkeys.Wnd)
member.summary: Gets the programming name of a Windows Forms control. Returns null if it is not a Windows Forms control or if fails.
member.param: The control. Can be top-level window too.
member.remarks: This function is easy to use and does not throw excaptions. However, when you need names of multiple controls of a single window, better create a WinFormsControlNames instance (once) and for each control call its GetControlNameOrText method, it will be faster.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.Misc.AllWindows(System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gets list of top-level windows. Returns list containing 0 or more window handles as Wnd. Calls API EnumWindows. The list can be bigger than you expect. See also MainWindows.
member.param: Need only visible windows.
Place all list elements of hidden windows at the end of the returned list, even if the hidden windows are before some visible windows in the Z order.
member.remarks: By default the list elements are sorted to match the Z order. On Windows 8 and later gets only desktop windows, not Windows Store app Metro-style windows (on Windows 10 only few such windows exist), unless this process has UAC integrity level uiAccess; to get such windows you can use FindFast.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.Misc.ThreadWindows(System.Int32,System.Boolean,System.Func{Catkeys.Wnd,System.Boolean})
member.summary: Gets list of top-level windows of a thread. Returns list containing 0 or more window handles as Wnd. Calls API EnumThreadWindows.
member.param: Unmanaged thread id. See , . If 0, throws exception. If other invalid value (ended thread?), returns empty list. Supports .
Need only visible windows.
Lambda etc callback function to call for each matching window. It can evaluate more properties of the window and return true when they match. Example: also: t => t.ClassNameIs("#32770").
member.exception: 0 threadId.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.Misc.FindThreadWindow(System.Int32,System.String,System.String,Catkeys.WFFlags,System.Func{Catkeys.Wnd,System.Boolean})
member.summary: Finds window of the specified thread. Returns its handle as Wnd. Returns Wnd0 if not found. Parameters are the same as of .
member.param: Unmanaged thread id. See , . If 0, throws exception. If other invalid value (ended thread?), returns Wnd0.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Wnd.Misc.WndActiveOfThisThread
member.summary: Gets the active window of this thread. Calls API GetActiveWindow.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Wnd.Misc.WndTop
member.summary: Gets the very first top-level window in the Z order. Usually it is a topmost window. Calls API GetTopWindow(Wnd0).

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.Misc.WndFirstEnabledOwnedOrThis(Catkeys.Wnd)
member.summary: Gets the first (top) enabled window in the chain of windows owned by w, or w itself if there are no such windows. Calls API GetWindow(w, GW_ENABLEDPOPUP).
member.remarks: Supports .

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.Misc.WndLastSeenActiveOwnedOrThis(Catkeys.Wnd)
member.summary: Gets the most recently active window owned by w, or w itself if it was the most recently active. Calls API GetLastActivePopup(w).
member.remarks: Supports .

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.Misc.WndRootOwnerOrThis(Catkeys.Wnd)
member.summary: Gets the most bottom owner window in the chain of owner windows of w. If w is not owned, returns w. Calls API GetAncestor(GA_ROOTOWNER).
member.remarks: Supports .

member.name: P:Catkeys.Wnd.Misc.WndRoot
member.summary: Gets the virtual parent window of all top-level windows. Calls API GetDesktopWindow. It is not the visible desktop window (see ).

member.name: P:Catkeys.Wnd.Misc.WndShell
member.summary: Gets a window of the shell process (usually process "explorer", class name "Progman"). Calls API GetShellWindow. In most cases it is not the window that contains desktop icons (see ). But it belongs to the same thread.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Wnd.Misc.WndDesktop
member.summary: Gets the desktop window. It displays desktop icons and wallpaper in its child control . The "Show Desktop" command (Win+D) activates it. It is not the same as API GetDesktopWindow (see ). This function is not very reliable. May stop working on a new Windows version or don't work with a custom shell.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Wnd.Misc.WndDesktopControl
member.summary: Gets the control of "SysListView32" class that contains desktop icons and wallpaper. It is a child of . This function is not very reliable. May stop working on a new Windows version or don't work with a custom shell.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.Misc.MainWindows(System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Get windows that have taskbar button and/or are included in the Alt+Tab sequence. Returns list containing 0 or more window handles as Wnd.
member.param: See .
See .
member.remarks: The list order does not match the order of buttons in the Windows taskbar. Possibly also does not exactly match the list of Alt+Tab windows.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.Misc.SwitchActiveWindow
member.summary: Activates next non-minimized main window, like with Alt+Tab. Returns true if activated, false if there is no such window or failed to activate. Calls WndNextMain and . An alternative way - send Alt+Tab keys, but it works not everywhere; it can activate a minimized window too.

member.name: T:Catkeys.Wnd.Misc.SpecHwnd
member.summary: Can be used with some functions as a special window handle value. It is implicitly converted to Wnd.

member.summary: Creates native/unmanaged message-only window. Styles: WS_POPUP, WS_EX_NOACTIVATE. Later call or .

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.Misc.DestroyWindow(Catkeys.Wnd)
member.summary: Destroys a native window of this thread. Calls API DestroyWindow. Returns false if failed. Supports .

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.Misc.GetWindowsStoreAppId(Catkeys.Wnd,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gets window Windows Store app user model id, like "Microsoft.WindowsCalculator_8wekyb3d8bbwe!App". Returns null if fails or if called on Windows 7.
member.param: Prepend @"shell:AppsFolder\" (to run or get icon).
Get program path if it is not a Windows Store app.
member.remarks: Windows Store app window class name can be "Windows.UI.Core.CoreWindow" or "ApplicationFrameWindow".

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.Misc.GetIconHandle(Catkeys.Wnd,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gets icon that is displayed in window title bar and in its taskbar button. Returns icon handle if successful, else Zero. Later call or .
member.param: Get 32x32 icon. If false, gets 16x16 icon.
member.remarks: Icon size depends on DPI (text size, can be changed in Control Panel). By default small is 16, large 32. This function can be used with windows of any process.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.Misc.SetIconHandle(Catkeys.Wnd,System.IntPtr,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Sets native icon handle. Sends message API WM_SETICON. Does not copy the icon; don't dispose it while the window is alive. Use this function only with windows of current process.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.Misc.GetFontHandle(Catkeys.Wnd)
member.summary: Gets native font handle. Sends message API WM_GETFONT. Does not copy the font; don't need to dispose. Use this function only with windows of current process.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.Misc.SetFontHandle(Catkeys.Wnd,System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Sets native font handle. Sends message API WM_SETFONT with lParam 1. Does not copy the font; don't dispose it while the window is alive. Use this function only with windows of current process.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.Misc.StringRemoveUnderlineAmpersand(System.String@)
member.summary: Removes '&' characters from string. Replaces "&&" to "&". Returns true if s had '&' characters.
member.remarks: Character '&' is used to underline next character in displayed text of dialog controls and menu items. Two '&' are used to display single '&'. The underline is displayed when using the keyboard (eg Alt key) to select dialog controls and menu items.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.ThrowIf0
member.summary: If , throws .

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.ThrowIfInvalid
member.summary: If or !, throws .

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.ThrowUseNative
member.summary: Throws that uses the last Windows API error (code and message). Also the message depends on whether the window handle is 0/invalid.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.ThrowUseNative(System.String)
member.summary: Throws that uses mainMessage and the last Windows API error (code and message). Also the message depends on whether the window handle is 0/invalid.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.ThrowNoNative(System.String)
member.summary: Throws that uses mainMessage and does not use the last Windows API error. Also the message depends on whether the window handle is 0/invalid.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Wnd.Is0
member.summary: Returns true if the handle is 0 ().

example.code: Wnd w = Wnd.Find("Window*"); if(w.Is0) { Print("window not found"); return; }

member.name: P:Catkeys.Wnd.IsAlive
member.summary: Returns true if the handle identifies an existing window. Returns false if the handle is 0 or invalid. Invalid non-0 handle usually means that the window is closed/destroyed.
member.remarks: Calls and API IsWindow. Although a Wnd variable holds a window handle, which is like a reference to a window, it does not prevent closing that window and making the handle invalid. After closing the window, the OS can even assign the same handle value to a new window, although normally it can happen only after long time. Use this carefully with windows of other applications or threads. The window can be closed at any moment, even when your thread is still in this function.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Wnd.IsVisible
member.summary: Gets the visible state. Returns true if the window is visible. Returns false if is invisible or is a child of invisible parent. Also returns false when fails (probably window closed or 0 handle). Supports .
member.remarks: Calls API IsWindowVisible. This function is unaware about cloaked windows. If need, use code if(w.IsVisible && !w.IsCloaked). This function is unaware about transparent windows, zero-size windows, zero-window-region windows, off-screen windows and windows that are completely covered by other windows.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.Show(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Shows (if hidden) or hides this window. Does not activate/deactivate/zorder. With windows of current thread usually it's better to use ShowLL.
member.remarks: Calls API ShowWindow with SW_SHOWNA or SW_HIDE.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.ShowLL(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Shows (if hidden) or hides this window. Does not activate/deactivate/zorder.
member.remarks:
This library has two similar functions - Show and ShowLL. Show is better to use in automation scripts, with windows of any process/thread. ShowLL usually is better to use in programming, with windows of current thread. ShowLL is more low-level. Does not throw exception when fails, and does not add a delay; Show adds a small delay when the window is of other thread.
Calls API ShowWindow with SW_SHOWNA or SW_HIDE. Supports .

member.name: P:Catkeys.Wnd.IsEnabled
member.summary: Gets the enabled state. Returns true if the window is enabled. Returns false if is disabled or is a child of disabled parent. Also returns false when fails (probably window closed or 0 handle). Supports . Calls API IsWindowEnabled.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.Enable(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Enables or disables the window. Calls API EnableWindow.
member.param: Enable or disable.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Wnd.IsCloakedGetState
member.summary: Gets the cloaked state. Returns 0 if not cloaked or if failed. Else returns flags: 1 cloaked by its application, 2 cloaked by Windows, 4 cloaked because its owner window is cloaked. On Windows 7 returns 0 because there is no "cloaked window" feature.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Wnd.IsCloaked
member.summary: Returns true if the window is cloaked. Returns false if not cloaked or if failed. On Windows 7 returns false because there is no "cloaked window" feature. Windows 10 uses window cloaking mostly to hide windows on inactive desktops. Windows 8 - mostly to hide Metro app windows.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Wnd.IsMinimized
member.summary: Returns true if minimized, false if not. Also returns false when fails (probably window closed or 0 handle). Supports . Calls API IsIconic.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Wnd.IsMaximized
member.summary: Returns true if maximized, false if not. Also returns false when fails (probably window closed or 0 handle). Supports . Calls API IsZoomed.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.ShowMinimized(System.Boolean)
member.summary: If not minimized, minimizes. Also unhides.
member.param: Visually fast, without animation.
member.exception: The API call failed. No exception if the window did not obey.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.ShowMaximized(System.Boolean)
member.summary: If not minimized, minimizes. Also unhides.
member.param: Visually fast, without animation.
member.exception: The API call failed. No exception if the window did not obey.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.ShowNotMinMax(System.Boolean)
member.summary: If maximized or minimized, makes normal (not min/max). Also unhides.
member.param: Visually fast, without animation.
member.exception: The API call failed. No exception if the window did not obey.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.ShowNotMinimized(System.Boolean)
member.summary: If minimized, restores previous non-minimized state (maximized or normal). Also unhides.
member.param: Visually fast, without animation.
member.exception: The API call failed. No exception if the window did not obey.

member.summary: Sets window min/max/normal/restore state. Also unhides.
member.param: Must be SW_MINIMIZE, SW_RESTORE (restores to normal/max if minimized), SW_SHOWNORMAL or SW_SHOWMAXIMIZED.
Use SetWindowPlacement (no animation).

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.LibGetWindowPlacement(Catkeys.Api.WINDOWPLACEMENT@,System.String)
member.summary: Initializes a WINDOWPLACEMENT struct and calls API GetWindowPlacement.
member.remarks: Supports .
member.exception: Failed. Throws, only if errStr!=null, else returns false.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.LibSetWindowPlacement(Catkeys.Api.WINDOWPLACEMENT@,System.String)
member.summary: Sets WINDOWPLACEMENT length field and calls API SetWindowPlacement.
member.exception: Failed. Throws, only if errStr!=null, else returns false.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.Activate
member.summary: Activates this window (brings to the foreground). Also unhides, restores minimized etc, to ensure that the window is ready to receive sent keys, mouse clicks ect.
member.remarks:
Activating a window usually also uncloaks it, for example switches to its virtual desktop on Windows 10. Fails (throws exception) if cannot activate this window, except:
If this is a control, activates its top-level parent window.
If this is , just deactivates the currently active window.
When the target application instead activates another window of the same thread.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.LibActivate(System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Activates this window (brings to the foreground). The same as , but has some options.
member.param: Don't activate if has WS_EX_NOACTIVATE style or is toolwindow without caption, unless cloaked. Then returns true.
Wait for window animations to end. Eg when switching Win10 desktops.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.ActivateLL
member.summary: Low-level version of . Just calls , API SetForegroundWindow and makes sure that it actually worked, but does not check whether it activated exactly this window. No exceptions, does not unhide, does not restore minimized, does not check is it a top-level window or control, etc. Returns false if fails.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.LibAllowActivate(System.Boolean)
member.summary: No exceptions.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd._AllowActivate_SendKey(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Sends a key (VK_0 up). It allows to activate now. Later this process can always activate easily (without key etc). It works even with higher IL windows. Don't know why is this behavior. Tested on all OS from XP to 10. Does not work if the foreground process has higher UAC IL.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd._AllowActivate_MinRes
member.summary: Creates a temporary minimized window and restores it. It activates the window and allows us to activate. Then sets 'no active window' to prevent auto-activating another window when destroying the temporary window.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd._AllowActivate_AllowSetFore
member.summary: Calls Api.AllowSetForegroundWindow(Api.GetCurrentProcessId()).

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.Focus
member.summary: Sets the keyboard input focus to this control or window. Also activetes its top-level parent window (see ). Can belong to any process/thread. With controls of this thread you can use the more lightweight function .
member.remarks: Can instead focus a child control. For example, if this is a ComboBox, it will focus its child Edit control. Then does not throw exception.
member.exception: Invalid handle; disabled; failed to set focus; failed to activate parent window. Fails to set focus when the target process is admin and this process is normal.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.FocusLL
member.summary: Sets the keyboard input focus to this control or window. Does nothing if it belongs to another thread or its top-level parent window isn't the active window. Calls API SetFocus.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Wnd.WndFocused

member.name: P:Catkeys.Wnd.WndFocusedLL

member.name: P:Catkeys.Wnd.IsFocused
member.summary: Returns true if this is the control or window that has the keyboard input focus. Can belong to any process/thread. With controls of this thread you can use the more lightweight function . Calls .

member.summary: Resizes. Calls API SetWindowPos with flags SWP_NOMOVE|SWP_NOZORDER|SWP_NOOWNERZORDER|SWP_NOACTIVATE|swpFlagsToAdd. The same as ResizeLL, but does not support optional coordinates.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.MoveLL(System.Nullable{System.Int32},System.Nullable{System.Int32},System.Nullable{System.Int32},System.Nullable{System.Int32},System.UInt32)
member.summary: Moves and/or resizes.
member.remarks:
This library has two similar functions - Move and MoveLL. Move is better to use in automation scripts, with windows of any process/thread. MoveLL usually is better to use in programming, with windows of current thread. MoveLL is more low-level than Move (which can throw exceptions, supports fractional/workarea coordinates, restores if min/max, does not support SWP_ flags).
Calls API SetWindowPos. Supports .
For top-level windows use screen coordinates. For controls - direct parent client coordinates.
member.param: Left. Can be null to not move in X axis.
Top. Can be null to not move in Y axis.
Width. Can be null to not change width.
Height. Can be null to not change height.
One or more Native.SWP_ flags, except SWP_NOMOVE, SWP_NOSIZE, SWP_NOZORDER, SWP_NOOWNERZORDER, SWP_NOACTIVATE.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.MoveLL(System.Nullable{System.Int32},System.Nullable{System.Int32})
member.summary: Moves. Calls MoveLL(x, y, null, null, 0).
member.remarks:
This library has two similar functions - Move and MoveLL. Move is better to use in automation scripts, with windows of any process/thread. MoveLL usually is better to use in programming, with windows of current thread. MoveLL is more low-level than Move (which can throw exceptions, supports fractional/workarea coordinates, restores if min/max).
Calls API SetWindowPos. Supports .
For top-level windows use screen coordinates. For controls - direct parent client coordinates.
member.param: Left. Can be null to not move in X axis.
Top. Can be null to not move in Y axis.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.ResizeLL(System.Nullable{System.Int32},System.Nullable{System.Int32})
member.summary: Resizes. Calls MoveLL(null, null, width, height, 0).
member.remarks:
This library has two similar functions - Resize and ResizeLL. Resize is better to use in automation scripts, with windows of any process/thread. ResizeLL usually is better to use in programming, with windows of current thread. ResizeLL is more low-level than Resize (which can throw exceptions, supports fractional/workarea coordinates, restores if min/max).
Calls API SetWindowPos. Supports .
For top-level windows use screen coordinates. For controls - direct parent client coordinates.
member.param: Width. Can be null to not change width.
Height. Can be null to not change height.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.Move(System.Nullable{Catkeys.Types{System.Int32,System.Single}},System.Nullable{Catkeys.Types{System.Int32,System.Single}},System.Nullable{Catkeys.Types{System.Int32,System.Single}},System.Nullable{Catkeys.Types{System.Int32,System.Single}},System.Boolean)
member.summary: Moves and/or resizes. With windows of current thread usually it's better to use MoveLL.
member.param: Left. Can be int (pixels) or float (fraction of screen or work area or direct parent client area) or null to not move in X axis.
Top. Can be int (pixels) or float (fraction of screen or work area or direct parent client area) or null to not move in Y axis.
Width. Can be int (pixels) or float (fraction of screen or work area or direct parent client area) or null to not change width.
Height. Can be int (pixels) or float (fraction of screen or work area or direct parent client area) or null to not change height.
If false, the coordinates are relative to the primary screen, else to its work area. Not used when this is a child window.
member.remarks: Also restores the visible top-level window if it is minimized or maximized. For top-level windows use screen coordinates. For controls - direct parent client coordinates.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.Move(System.Nullable{Catkeys.Types{System.Int32,System.Single}},System.Nullable{Catkeys.Types{System.Int32,System.Single}},System.Boolean)
member.summary: Moves. Calls Move(x, y, null, null, workArea). With windows of current thread usually it's better to use MoveLL.
member.param: Left. Can be int (pixels) or float (fraction of screen or work area or direct parent client area) or null to not move in X axis.
Top. Can be int (pixels) or float (fraction of screen or work area or direct parent client area) or null to not move in Y axis.
If false, the coordinates are relative to the primary screen, else to its work area. Not used when this is a child window.
member.remarks: Also restores the visible top-level window if it is minimized or maximized. For top-level windows use screen coordinates. For controls - direct parent client coordinates.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.Resize(System.Nullable{Catkeys.Types{System.Int32,System.Single}},System.Nullable{Catkeys.Types{System.Int32,System.Single}},System.Boolean)
member.summary: Resizes. Calls Move(null, null, width, height, workArea). With windows of current thread usually it's better to use ResizeLL.
member.param: Width. Can be int (pixels) or float (fraction of screen or work area or direct parent client area) or null to not change width.
Height. Can be int (pixels) or float (fraction of screen or work area or direct parent client area) or null to not change height.
If false, fractional width/height are part of the primary screen, else of its work area. Not used when this is a child window.
member.remarks: Also restores the visible top-level window if it is minimized or maximized.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.MoveInScreen(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Object,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Moves this window to coordinates x y in specified screen, and ensures that entire window is in screen. By default, 0 and negative x y are interpreted as: 0 - screen center, <0 - relative to the right or bottom edge of the screen.
member.param: X coordinate in the specified screen.
Y coordinate in the specified screen.
Move to this screen. If null, use screen of this window. The same as with .
Use the work area, not whole screen.
If window is bigger than screen, resize it.
Don't interpret 0 and negative x y in a special way. They are relative to the top-left corner of the screen.
member.remarks: If the window is maximized, minimized or hidden, it will have the new position and size when restored, not immediately, except when moving maximized to another screen.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.EnsureInScreen(System.Object,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Moves this window if need, to ensure that entire window is in screen.
member.param: Move to this screen. If null, use screen of this window. See .
Use the work area, not whole screen.
If window is bigger than screen, resize it.
member.remarks: If the window is maximized, minimized or hidden, it will have the new position and size when restored, not immediately.

member.param: Move to this screen. If null, use screen of this window. See .

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.ZorderAbove(Catkeys.Wnd)
member.summary: Places this window before window w in the Z order. Also can make this window topmost or non-topmost, depending on where w is in the Z order. This window and w can be both top-level windows or both controls of same parent. May not work with top-level windows when it would move an inactive window above the active window. If w is Wnd0, calls .
member.remarks: Supports .

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.ZorderBelow(Catkeys.Wnd)
member.summary: Places this window after window w in the Z order. Also can make this window topmost or non-topmost, depending on where w is in the Z order. This window and w can be both top-level windows or both controls of same parent. May not work with top-level windows when it would move an inactive window above the active window. If w is Wnd0, calls .
member.remarks: Supports .

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.ZorderTop
member.summary: Places this window or control at the top of the Z order. If the window was topmost, it will be at the top of topmost windows, else at the top of non-topmost windows (after topmost windows). Does not activate. In most cases does not work with top-level inactive windows; instead use .
member.remarks: Supports .

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.ZorderBottom
member.summary: Places this window or control at the bottom of the Z order. If the window was topmost, makes it and its owner window non-topmost.
member.remarks: Supports .

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.ZorderTopmost
member.summary: Makes this window topmost (always on top of non-topmost windows in the Z order). Does not activate. If this window has an owner window, the owner does not become topmost. Thic cannot be a control.
member.remarks: Supports .

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.ZorderNotopmost(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Makes this window non-topmost. If this window has an owner window, makes the owner window non-topmost too. Thic cannot be a control.
member.param: Also place this window after the active nontopmost window in the Z order, unless the active window is its owner.
member.remarks: Supports .

member.name: P:Catkeys.Wnd.Name
member.summary: Gets window or control name. Returns "" if no name. Returns null if fails, eg if the window is closed. Supports .
member.remarks: It is not the .NET Control.Name property. To get it you can use . Top-level window name usually its title bar text. Control name usually is its text that does not change, for example button or static (label) control text. Unlike , this function usually does not get variable text, for example Edit control editable text, ComboBox control selected item text, status bar text. Calls (false, true).

member.name: P:Catkeys.Wnd.ControlText
member.summary: Gets control text. Returns "" if no text. Returns null if fails, eg if the window is closed. Supports .
member.remarks: Unlike , this function prefers variable text, for example Edit control editable text, ComboBox control selected item text, status bar text. For controls that cannot have such text (eg button, static), it usually gets the same text as Name. For example button and static (label) controls. Much slower than Name. Fails if the window is hung. Calls (true, false).

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.GetText(System.Nullable{System.Boolean},System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gets window/control name or control text. Returns "" if it is empty. Returns null if fails, eg if the window is closed. Supports . This is a low-level function. You can instead use and .
member.param: false - use API function InternalGetWindowText. It is fast and usually does not get variable text. This is used by . true - use API message WM_GETTEXT. It is slow and prefers variable text. This is used by . Fails if the window is hung. null - try InternalGetWindowText. If it gets "", and this is a control, then try WM_GETTEXT.
Remove the invisible '&' characters that are used to underline keyboard shortcuts with the Alt key. Removes only if this is a control (has style Native.WS_CHILD). Calls .

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd._GetTextFast(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gets text. Returns "" if it is empty. Returns null if fails, eg if the control is destroyed or its thread is hung. Supports . Calls API InternalGetWindowText. If it fails, and getControlTextIfEmpty==true, and this is a control, calls _GetTextSlow, which uses WM_GETTEXT.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd._GetTextSlow
member.summary: Gets text. Returns "" if it is empty. Returns null if fails, eg if the control is destroyed or its thread is hung. Supports . Uses WM_GETTEXT.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.SetText(System.String)
member.summary: Sets window/control name or control text.
member.param: Text. Can be null, it is the same as "".
member.remarks: Uses API WM_SETTEXT. Top-level window name usually its title bar text. For variable-text controls (edit, combo box, status bar, ...) this usually is the text that would get. For other controls (button, static, ...) and top-level windows this usually is the text that would get.
member.exception: Failed, for example the window is closed.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Wnd.NameWinForms
member.summary: Gets Control.Name property of a .NET Windows Forms control. Returns null if it is not a Windows Forms control or if fails. Use this with controls of other processes. Don't use with your controls, when you have a Control object. This is slow when getting names of multiple controls in a window. Instead create a instance and call its method for each control.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Wnd.ProcessName
member.summary: Gets filename (without ".exe") of process executable file. Return null if fails. Calls and Process_.GetProcessName.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Wnd.ProcessPath
member.summary: Gets full path of process executable file. Return null if fails. Calls and Process_.GetProcessName.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.Close(System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Closes the window. Returns true if successfuly closed or if it was already closed (the handle is 0 or invalid) or if noWait==true.
member.param: If false (default), waits a while until the window is destroyed or disabled. But does not wait indefinitely. If true, does not wait.

If false (default), uses API message WM_CLOSE. If true, uses API message WM_SYSCOMMAND SC_CLOSE, like when the user clicks the X button in the title bar. Most windows can be closed with any of these messages, but some respond properly only to one of them. For example, some applications on WM_CLOSE don't exit, although the main window is closed. Some applications don't respond to WM_SYSCOMMAND if it is posted soon after opening the window, for example Internet Explorer.
member.remarks: The window may refuse to be closed. For example, it may be hung, or hide itself instead, or display a "Save?" message box, or is a dialog without X button, or just need more time to close it. If the window is of this thread, just calls Send (if noWait==false) or Post (if noWait==true) and returns true.

example.code: //close all Notepad windows Wnd.FindAll("* Notepad", "Notepad").ForEach(t => t.Close());

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.Child(System.String,System.String,Catkeys.WCFlags,System.Func{Catkeys.Wnd,System.Boolean},System.Int32)
member.summary: Finds child control. Returns its handle as Wnd. Returns Wnd0 if not found.
member.param:
Control name. By default the function gets control names with . Can start with these prefix strings:
"**text:" - use control text, which can be editable. To get it this function uses . It is slower and can be less reliable (because can get editable text), especially if className not used. It does not remove the invisible '&' characters that are used to underline keyboard shortcuts with the Alt key.
"**accName:" - use MSAA IAccessible.Name property. To get it this function uses . It is slower.
"**wfName:" - use .NET Windows Forms Control Name property. To get it this function uses . It is slower and can fail because of UAC.
"**id:" (like "**id:15") - use control id. To get it this function uses . Cannot be wildcard expression. You can instead use , it is faster than Child.
String format (not including the prefix): wildcard expression. null means 'any'. "" means 'no name'.
Control class name. String format: wildcard expression. null means 'any'.
Lambda etc callback function to call for each matching control. It can evaluate more properties of the control and return true when they match. Example: also: t => t.IsEnabled
0-based index of matching control. For example, if it is 1, the function skips the first matching control and returns the second.
member.exception: This variable is invalid (window not found, closed, etc).
className is "". To match any, use null. Invalid wildcard expression ("**options|" or regular expression).

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.ChildById(System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Finds child control by its id. Finds hidden controls too. Does not prefer visible controls.
member.param: Control id.
Must be direct child, not a child of a child and so on.
member.remarks: Faster and more lightweight than Child. At first calls API GetDlgItem. It is fast and searches only direct children. If it does not find, and directChild is false, calls API EnumChildWindows. Not all controls have a useful id. If control id is 0 or different in each window instance, this function cannot be used.
member.exception: This variable is invalid (window not found, closed, etc).
